summary: The project manager recapped the decisions made in the previous meeting and two team members presented three prototypes which differed primarily in shape. The team felt it was not necessary to include a feature to prevent the remote from getting lost as the prototype designs were quite bright. The team conducted a product evaluation of the prototype the team liked the most. They rated the prototype on the basis of its appearance, functionality, technological innovativeness, sponginess, usability, learn-ability, its ability to be found when misplaced, simplicity, and its ability to meet the appropriate demographic. The team then discussed the production costs of the remote and what features they should retain or lose in order to maintain their target cost. The project manager then led the team in a project evaluation in which the team evaluated how they created the project, the information they found and used, their creativity, their teamwork, and the materials they had at their disposal. The team was generally quite satisfied. After the project manager's closing, the team discussed their personal preferences in terms of the prototypes. They also further evaluated the project process and discussed what they had learned.
decisions: The remote will resemble the potato prototype. There will be no feature to help find the remote when it is misplaced; instead the remote will be in a bright color to address this issue. The corporate logo will be on the remote. One of the color concepts for the remote will contain the corporate colors. The remote will have six buttons. The buttons will all be one color. The case will be single curve. The case will be made of rubber. The case will have a special color.
problems: Whether or not to have a feature which helps find the remote when it is misplaced.

[DECISIONS]   Name all decisions = that were=20 made during the meeting. Mark those decisions that you consider of = high=20 importance for your role with a *. Write fragmented notes.

          &= nbsp;=20 Simplicity and = Fashion

 

*=20  Usability is also an important feature.

Anti-loss=20 device

*Large=20 buttons for essential features

*Small=20 buttons (possibly 'hidden' away) for less useful = functions.

Fashionable=20 appearance

Long-life=20 battery

 

 

[PROBLEMS/ISSUES] Name=20 the problems or difficulties that occurred during the meeting. Mark = those that=20 you consider of high importance for your role with a *. Write = fragmented=20 notes.

[ABSTRACT] Write one paragraph of coherent text to summarize the = meeting as a whole from your role's perspective=20 =20 A meeting was held at 14:20 on 4th February 2005 to discuss the = conceptual design for the new TV remote control project. The previous = meeting was reviewed, with particular emphasis on our design goals: = simplicity and fashion. The industrial designer made a presentation = describing the different materials and components we might be able to = use. The user interface designer suggested some simple design concepts = around which a detailed design can be made. The marketing manager = discussed current trends in fashion that will influence our design = decisions. The meeting concluded with a lively discussion on the fashion = and design of the product. =20 [DECISIONS] Name all decisions that were made during the meeting. = Mark those decisions that you consider of high importance for your role = with a *. The group had performed sucessfully in producing the final project.

None.

Minutes- Kick-Off Meeting
- compiled by R. Lindgren
See powerpoint slides for agenda.
Introductions
Alima- Industrial Designer
Drew a Turtle ‘pretty little shell’
Nice to carry your home around
Iain- User Interface Designer
Whale- quiet intelligence, kind of mysterious
Jessie- Marketing
Seal- playful and silly
Rose- Project Manager
Coyote- sings to the moon, beautiful animal, association with home
Discussion
J = Jessie, I = Iain, A = Alima, R = Rose
J
Hate when 4 different buttons to turn on the TV
Not good to combine remotes together
Multi-media overload
Maybe need a device to help find it
I
Very good to have a remote
‘lazy’- don’t have to get up
have to use 3 different remotes for each function
too complicated, too many buttons
A
Too many- father has a whole drawer of remotes
Needs to be easy to use- not too many buttons, not too small
How to make infrared work without having to move the remote around
J
Batteries- do all remotes have to use?
R
What about a lithium battery?  Longer lasting
A
Make a remote with only essential functions, maybe with a separate one with special functions
Need large buttons
I
Is this project just for designing a remote specifically for television?
R- good question, I’ll try to look into it
